values:
She told me, on the phone today, that she is so proud of me. That perhaps she over-reacted the other day but she's just so proud of me. She said that my practicum was probably the hardest of anyone's, that it was the most valuable. She said that I have great drive and tenacity.

Who is this woman?

So on Friday she observed me and it went well. I could feel it going well. One of my sister's woke up at the time I was starting and prayed to our great great grandmother who was herself a teacher, and radical for her time. Everything she prayed for is what I got... and I never have that during observation: comfort, humour, fun, energy.

Anyways, my FA came up to me after and cupped my face in her hands while spouting that she was so proud of me. She started talking about how it takes everyone a different amount of time to 'arrive'. I responded in saying that I have been 'there' before, but I just happened to feel more comfortable finally during this observation. She cut me off and said 'No excuses, just say thank you'. Ok.

She said she could finally see me as a teacher.

What I see now is this: the other class was so difficult, of course I never felt comfortable with observation. With this new sweethearted class, I didn't feel comfortable during the first observation because of my bad experience with observation during the last class. The second observation wasn't very comfortable either because she stayed a long time, longer than usual, and I hadn't heard feedback from my last one. The third one, I had written feedback from my second yet no verbal, but I had just stopped caring so that helped. However, I figure if I had had a sweet-ish class from the get-go, I would have been fine. Richer experience, fine, now that it's near over. I have one more observation tomorrow, then Friday is the end. I still have to be observed twice by my school associate and once by the vice-principal (we have no principal). On Thursday after school, I have to have my final evaluation done (which is totally unfair and ridiculous!). I'm lucky cuz my sister is going to help me. Never would have passed without that one.

PS. I have mostly been writing on <lj user="v3g4n"> cuz I'm tired. Maybe one day I'll transfer it over here in a moment of excess and orderliness.

That was my last day in that class. Hurray for me. I listened to her teach them, and just silently cheered that they were all hers now.

<lj-cut>So I get to see my new class tomorrow. 3 days of observation/integration, then spring break to plan. Then teaching for 3.5 weeks. Longer than I had previously thought.

My faculty associate was not happy with me once again. She came to see me, and stood in the class while the children said goodbye to me for the last time. That's brutal. She shouldn't be in there, observing me for my last moments with them. Did I ever mention how she totally invaded my personal life, asking me about anti-depressants and counselling (and suggesting both)? She seems to think that she understands who people are - does she not realize that there is a power dynmamic and a particular situation, so this is not who I am? She thinks that her and the other student teacher at my school are the same 'kind of people', with which that student teacher disagrees. The FA told that student teacher that people like them might never find love. WTF? So talking to the student, the FA asks if her current relationship is a 'sane love'. She is trying to bond with students, and she's crossing lines she should not. Looking into her eyes today, I was picturing her as an evil force that I had to be strong against - how weird is that?

Oh, so why she wasn't happy with me: She started going off about how I am more defined now. I started stuttering and stumbling with a response and I knew that I wasn't able to produce what she wanted. That's my problem, I have major trouble faking. So she mentioned that I seemed unsure. I explained that I'm not quite sure what she means by defined. She went off about how I'm coming into my own. Vague party. Look, I was given a really hard class, that's it lady. Sure, I'll seem more comfortable in the new class - because they aren't hellions. She just won't say it - social politics.

Speaking of social politics, I had my first ever parent teacher interview. I let my sponsor teacher do most of the talking. It's interesting. The teachers are out to protect themselves from brutal parents. You get burned once and you stop sharing information? I hope that I can be more open with my parents, or have more substantial information for them.

I gave my sponsor teacher some Starbucks coffee for a parting gift. Gross. At least it was fair trade. My consumer politics have gone down the tube during this practicum. Not completely, but dramatically.

Funniest thing of the week: The teacher and I were watching one of the kids presenting on Chimpanzees, and this other kid sitting in his seat had tied his sweater around his waist... but had also accidentally tied it around his chair. We watched him try and get up as he was attached. Hilarious. Then he didn't untie it, he just tried to figure out a way to get unattached without untying it. FUNNY.

I heard today that at least two people dropped out of our program. Brutal, but this makes me feel better.

I'm excited about my new teacher and my new school. She sounds so nice and on top of things. The school sounds amazing. I am so hopeful.

I really hope to run in the morning before school. Exercise makes such a difference for me. It's just so hard to get up in the morning. Tonight I am going to bed at 8pm? Then maybe I can get up at 5:20am?

I am so sick. I really shouldn't be going to school. The days are brutal now. They were already brutal. Now the kids get away with more, and I deliver much less understandable lessons.

My sponsor teacher talked to me about their messy desks, and told me it wasn't a personal attack. What? Their desks have always been messy with her. I can see that they are possibly messier. I would love to make them have clean desks.

One boy's parents are concerned about using punishment with him, that he doesn't respond well to it. When you have a boy that never listens, that runs around and wrestles with others... that tells me to hurry up in explaining something (and I'm only explaining it to him because he wasn't listening in the first place)... and who does a million other inappropriate things... what the hell are we supposed to do? We've tried everything. It's fucking ridiculous.

I'm so excited to see what the other teacher does. If you don't already know, I've gotten a new placement (I've been posting more in my personal journal). I start on Wednesday, plan during spring break, then teach for 3 weeks. Hopefully I'll be in a better physical/mental state by the end of spring break. I need to have some fun before I start it all over again.

I really wish that I could stop teaching this class now. I'm so sick of them. There are some lovely kids (they are all lovely though, just not in this context), but the other ones I'll be happy to never see again. They kill me. I'm really hoping that the next class and the next teacher will reintill my hope and energy. So thankful that I get to leave.

Right now I'm so tired. I'd like to watch a movie and then go to sleep. I have to lesson plan. Hating it.

She said she is going to extend my practicum. This is hell. However, there were good things today:

[1] 3 girls in my class enlisting me to help them plan a secret birthday party for the sponsor teacher, and particularly 1 girl who was so respectful towards me during the planning

[1b] That 1 girl told me that her sister thinks I'm cool

[2] When the music lesson sucked and I scrapped it, and ended up dancing a bit silly and then had them do a congo line behind me to the cloakroom - and for once I had everyone doing the same thing

PS: After talking to my mother, I am going to see if I can pursue the option of choosing to have a weak reference letter from my faculty associate instead of extending my practicum. They are desparate for French teachers. I only want to sub in the beginning anyways. ANYTHING not to extend this practicum. Seriously.
So she sounds like she is not going to extend my practicum into April, but she suggested that I experience more of the new found joy with this class by teaching them for longer. FUCK YOU.

Well it was a pretty brutal week. I'm hopeful but very scared for the next week.

Just thought I'd post this link to a video here, passed on to me from my old sponsor teacher:

http://tedblog.typepad.com/tedblog/files/kenrobinson.html

It talks about educating the creativity out of children, and about the failings of curriculum hierarchy (math trumps art).

I'm kind of drunk. I came home to a cake that my roommates made for me. The beauty of my life. Glorious, really. Then we had wonderful dinner around a candle lit table... and drank wine.

Today was different. I chose less battles, picked less of them. I tried to be caring and supportive instead of their disciplinarian. I had more energy because of coffee. I tried to engage them instead of forcing them into compliance. It's weird to think of myself as a disciplinarian... as coming into a class and trying to whip them into shape. I found them so incredibly disrespectful, and I wanted to force it out of them. I treated tham as though they weren't capable of anything more. I'm rather embarassed, and shocked that I would behave so?

I have much to learn in terms of how to non-coercively engage them. I just have much to learn. It's interesting to hear advice coming from all sides, and try to find out what is honest for me. I think my FA went to far in kind of insinuating that anti-depressants might be an idea for me (but maybe I read too much into that?), but everyone has their things, and it's me that needs to stand up and figure out what's right for me.

I am learning, and that's all that matters. Being broken down to the point of fearing failure is allowing me to take greater risks. It's pretty awesome despite the outcome. I look forward to tomorrow. To delivering clearer lessons, to finding ways to engage them, to opening communication and community. Today (and every morning from now on), we had a circle share. We can share whatever we want... like what we liked about the previous day... what was challenging... etc. It's nice to sit together and just listen. We don't normally have that. These are things that I want in the future, but was not enacting in the present. I was trying to jump through the hoop, and putting of the good for tomorrow. Now I have to enact it.

I send myself strength and confidence. I will continue to try and connect and appreciate all of the students.

I started positive reinforcement today. You get a marble to add to the jar when you are doing something awesome. I give them out as often as possible. Maybe tomorrow we can introduce the idea of nominating other people for a marble... recognizing the awesomeness of our friends.

Right now, sometimes I feel so broken down - and I feel like I'm wearing the smile that one of the kids in my class does. This pained, fearful, panicked, trying to survive kind of smile. I feel so sorry for that boy. My FA is always telling me that it's not about me, that they are the focus. It's like how you learn that it's not about you at a party... you think about other people more... and things get easier.

I can't stop crying. I am so scared. My faculty associate is telling me not to be, that this is where I should be (according to the universe), and all that. She's hitting the nail on the head in regards to the problems I am having, but it's so brutal.

I really do just want to make it through this practicum, but perhaps I'll have to give that up. I mean it's great to let go, isn't it? If I'm not supposed to finish, I'm not supposed to finish. I'll have to grow more before I can do it, or never come back. I don't know.

I have a lot of fear, and stress and negative outlook when it comes to the world. Not all the time, but it's a large part of me. This comes out in my class. There are many great activities I see doing with my future class, but I haven't been doing with them. I'm scared. I just wanted to make it through. Now I'm not.

I can't fully explain all the problems in my class at the moment, but it's not good. I tried punishing them into compliance which is a bad move. Now I'm fairly lost. I have amazing support in that school, but I still don't know that I'll make it through.

She doesn't see me finding human connections with the students, and it's true. I don't feel safe, and so they don't either.

She talked to me about whether this is the right time for me to be doing this practicum. I understand, and I question it as well BUT that is so brutal. My parents have paid for this education, and then I couldn't get through it? My dad has given me the car.

Whatever though, right? I'll do my best. I'll try really hard with the idea that it's out of my control. I think it's partially unfair... but it's the cards I've been dealt. It sounds like I have to cancel my flight to France because I'll likely need to extend my practicum into April with another placement at another school.

I wish I had more confidence. Even during the science fair this afternoon, I felt really awkward amongst the students of the school. Partially to do with my ability to speak French, but also it's just me.

Today is the worst of the days.

I have to lesson plan for tomorrow, because my faculty associate is coming to observe me, and I can hardly stop crying.

My FA called me while I was crying. So I probably told her more than I should have. Part of my problem (?) with all of this, is that I can't just tell people what they want to hear. I just tell them what is actually happening.

So today my sponsor teacher told me that two of the boys feel that I don't like them. She told me that I need to find ways to compliment them - even if it's just about their shirt. She said that when they are sent to the other classroom, they feel that they are being demoted (it's a grade two class, and I have grade threes). So my sponsor teacher doesn't want me to send them there anymore,  except rarely. She also doesn't want me to send anyone out of the room before recess. I mean, I understand all of this. It's not fun for them, and it's not fun for me. It's authoritarian punishment. She told me that it's not working. I said that I thought it was, and she repeated that it wasn't.

But then I swing all ways. When I talk to the grade two teacher, I feel like all this punishment is fine. When I talk to my sister, I think my sponsor teacher just doesn't swing my way - and that she just doesn't like having firm systems. When I talk to my FA, I feel like it does make sense... and that I do need to find a different way. She suggests that I talk to the boys one on one, ask them how they feel about my systems so far, about being sent to the office/etc, and what they think would be fair?

She wants me to see each of them as a positive member of the classroom, to find the positive in them. I do too, but there's a block. I don't know how. I just don't know how when it comes to a lot of things in that class. And it plays on my lack of confidence. I'm gaining confidence, that's for sure, but I'm always incredibly aware of the lack. Today especially.

And a major factor of stress is the fear of not making it through this hoop. Fear that they'll decide that I'm not good enough. They all want different things from me, and I don't feel like I can give those things to them.

I'm learning. I don't know if I'd survive this if it were not for my sister, my amazing roommates and house, my father's car, etc. Yesterday up at campus, I wondered how a lot of these people are dealing with it. It's hard, and it seems that some of them have worse lots than I.

A kid left me a note today: "To Mme. Nicole, I'm not having much fun in math and other subgecs. Can you mack it funner. Pleas"

Need to see this positively. Need positive focus. Work a bit, go to bed. Tomorrow's crazy hair day. Third week, 3.5 to go.

Also, the gay teacher took me out for coffee after (cuz I drove her home). It was awesome, even though I was nervous... cuz that's my style. The staff at this school are SO supportive.

5pm. I've been home for a while. Listening to Justin Timberlake, playing on the Internet. I have the intention of going to the gym. Sometimes it's hard to commence leaving the house. I don't have everything planned for tomorrow... but I suppose I figure I can wing it? The more I can do so, the better for my mental health.

Today we were up at campus. I got to hear lots of horror stories. Makes me thankful for having a school with such great supportive staff. I'm also thankful for my incredibly supportive faculty associate and my laid back sponsor teacher. There are definite complaints, but for the most part, I've got a great deal.

I feel positive about it all, in a grand sense. Obviously it can get me down - it can be extremely overwhelming.

We talked about hiring today, which was interesting. Interviews and the like. My impression is that I'll be a substitute to begin with, which is good (except for the commuting). I get to find out where I really want to be, and learn about different teachers' strategies. Plus I can take any day off that I like.

Stay in the moment.

School today was decent. This is partly due to having Wednesday afternoon skating, Thursday off, and Friday afternoon off (and minus one of the most difficult kids).

I kind of love it when my sponsor teacher is not there. I feel completely comfortable to do what feels right. As soon as she walks into the room, I feel a bit nervous, and like I can't completely be myself.

I loved when one of the most resistant kids handed in his morning agenda work without me asking, for the first time. That was amazing.

I love seeing them habituate to my systems. I love the simple tool of counting seconds til they listen to me, and then keeping them in those seconds during recess. It's unfair, but so effective - and I can only be so fair. They have to group-regulate.

I love when kids that usually seem to detest me, engage in a hearty reciprocal smile with me. It's lovely. Today, while my sponsor teacher was teaching art, I watched them and really smiled with love for them - possibly for the first time? Even one boy who is very difficult, watching him pace around the room while she read a story - I just felt really appreciative of his situation in that he obviously has a hard time staying in one place.

Today I cried. I still feel like crying. I was so angry with the world on the way home.

I cried in between recess and lunch, and felt close to crying while teaching them. I had wonderful support from the learning assistance teacher, and then some from my sponsor teacher (but I usually end up feeling like she secretly disagrees with something that I'm doing - but just isn't saying it - she doesn't give me much advice - or so it feels).

After lunch, I took six of the most difficult and talked to them in a separate room. It didn't go so well. I mean what could I really say? They expressed how difficult it is for them to stay in their place. I said that I understood, and that it's unfortunate that we can't have lessons that meet their needs, but that I am one person and that I already stay up way too late preparing for their class. I mostly just lectured them. Sweet, the person I've always wanted to be.

Then I taught out the rest of the day trying to ignore them.

I either have to be stricter or more flexible. I either have to send them to the office or another teacher's classroom as soon as they lose their 3 chances (re: before recess) or I have to just let them do pretty much whatever they want - and just send them to the hallway, office or other class as I see fit (re: not that often?). I can still follow up on them finishing their school work. I found out that one boy who doesn't catch up during catch up time, because he doesn't want to, is allowed to be kept after school. Sweet.

I sat in on a meeting with a parent. My sponsor teacher explained the behaviour of the child, but she had no notes and didn't really address everything. It was a weird experience. It was nice to hear more about the kid through his mother. I was warned that she would be really intense, but I found her to be quite lovely. She told me that her kid doesn't like me. I told her that I know. Of course he doesn't. I have tried to make him do his work since I met him. He was disrespectful to me right away.

Anyways... adventures in institutional school. Today I am thinking that I would like to work one day per week for benefits and the go start some awesome co-ops or something instead. It's hard to know that not all classes are like this.

It's just so hard to know how to meet their needs (and thus mine).

I also feel like I'm trying to whip some kids into shape, kids who have been getting away with tons for five months. I'm not sure I want to do it.

I realize that we are lucky to have an education, but sometimes the institution seems so gross (well always in some way, but sometimes it just feels completely disgusting). And when you feel down on the world, it's easy to find problems (especially when you drive home through the rich areas).

Today I was excited about going. Really excited. Excited about my confidence, about being a teacher. I feel perfectly capable of handling them, and generally feel like I have them more under control than she did. However, that's easy to say when I am distracted by way more things than I was when I was observing. I am much happier being their teacher than just being that person that would chase after them all the time to do their work. I'm learning a lot about how to deliver lessons to 8 year olds - easy does it. I'm having the opportunity to use new systems - of my own choosing.

I talked to my faculty advisor today - best conversation yet. Totally from my end because I am feeling more confident, and because I have more to talk with her about. It was an important conversation for me, as I was feeling the need to hear again how she is supporting me and trusting me. I get worried about how well I'm doing, but I need to give myself more credit. I am constantly trying to find ways to better the situation in that class. Part of my problem is that I am thinking more about me than them. I know we're all linked, but I'm having trouble feeling a lot of compassion or concern for some of them. Granted, I haven't known them very long, so I can't expect to be too attached. However, I was thinking about my interactions with them, and how I do have some affect in terms of how they interact with life. On the other hand, I feel like there is no hope, and that I just have to survive them. The kid that poses the most problem has parents who hate the principal of the school (or so I hear - not to judge them without even meeting). Your family can dictate a lot for how you perceive and interact with the world. I get to meet with those parents next week. I've heard that they made two teachers' lives hell. The principal can't come to the meeting because they don't like him (sweetest principal I've ever met). It'll be interesting. I'm pretty excited.

Today one of the difficult boys said "Don't you have something better you could be doing?" when I tried to get him to do his work. I responded with "That's not appropriate. This is my job. My job is to get you to do your work. If I need to move you so that you work, I can do that."

Another kid was making it so hard to get him to do his work. He'd been pulled out of computer class to finish it. He was just refusing, and joking around. At some point he told me he didn't want to do it, and I said "I don't care." I was smiling though, and I know him well enough to know that he would find it funny. They're amazing kids, and they know that a lot of school is ridiculous. They're just having really bad attitudes about it. I've done and will continue to do the same in my own life.

Ok, then there was an incident today. <lj-cut>Kid X, Y and Z. All difficult kids. Though Z, less so. X and Y, the most difficult. X and Y are working. X says "North Korea is going to blow up my head." Y laughs. Z is Korean from South Korea. He gets upset and throws a tennis ball at X. Then Y grabs Z's soccer ball and runs off to the cloakroom with it. Z runs after Y, and pushes him in the cloakroom to get his ball back. Y falls and hurts himself. I come into the cloakroom, unaware of what has transpired. I see Y on the floor, and as a boy who causes a LOT of problems, I frustratedly tell him to get up. I get him to sit in a chair and see that he's in pain. I get everyone to leave the cloakroom so it's just him and I. He tells me a bit of what happened. This provides me with a much needed rare chance to be of comfort to him (we have nearly no positive rapport). I call Z over and tell them they both need to calm down, and that they are going to each tell me what happened, one at a time. I get both sides and find out all the information above. The conversation ends with Z so pissed off that he walks away dismissing Y. I did get to explain that it's not about who threw the hardest punch, it's that everyone has thrown punches now. The comment wasn't okay. It's not okay to take revenge by throwing something at someone. It's not okay to laugh at the comment, and not stand up against it. It's not okay to run away with someone's ball. Anyways, I left them both to be pissed at their desks. Then I talked to Y, and asked if he'd want to meet again after school. He declined. I told him that it sucks to be in this situation, that hopefully it'll be forgotten by tomorrow (sketchy of me), and that I get into situations that are uncomfortable like this with my friends and it feels rotten. I talked later to X and told him what I'd heard (that he said the comment). I said that I felt there was a problem, and asked him if he knew what it was. He said it was because Z comes from Korea. Then he protested that Z comes from South and not North Korea. I explained that those comments aren't appropriate even if a person from that country is not present. I talked about how Z feels hurt, and suggested X could apologize. I explained that Z might not say "thank you", and that Z might still act angry. I'm sure I made plenty of mistakes here. One is that I shouldn't have told X what I thought he should do, I should have told him that he needs to think of an appropriate restorative measure or else I would think of one for him. Yet even then, there were mistakes from all parties. Should I have a meeting with all of them? Let them talk one at a time? Have them use 'I' statements? It's pretty overwhelming. I have to talk to Z tomorrow and let him know that I talked to X.</lj-cut>

I might try to have class meetings. Keep an agenda list on the board. Teach concensus (with a fall back on voting?). Have a minutes taker, a speakers list taker and a facilitator on rotation?

In the morning today, one girl's mother came in to talk to me. "I don't know how to start this..." I wasn't nervous, I just wanted to hear what she had to say. Apparently her daughter cried last night because I put her name on the board. I have started to write subject names on the board, with the names of those who haven't finished the work below. This is because it's too hard for me to talk to them one at a time. 21 versus 1. She only had one thing to hand in, no big deal. Basically, I need to talk to her and ask her what she thought it was about - and explain what I meant. Then I need to address the class to let them know what I mean by it.

I'm dreaming of having a data projector (to project my computer screen on the wall). I want the Internet in my classroom.

My first full day of teaching. One down, twenty-nine to go. The first half of the day was great. The second half felt more like I bombed. Two of the difficult kids weren't there.

My sponsor teacher told me that she wished that one of the difficult kid's parents would drug him. Woah. I mean, I can understand her intentions. She recognizes that this is making the kid fit the system... but she also has to deal with the stress. However, it seems to me there are more things she could be doing. Yet they all deal with discipline. I'm no good with maintaining positive relationships with some of the kids. I mean, I can feel sorry for them... institutions can really blow. It's just that when they repeatedly defy me, and never listen to me (they pretend not to hear my voice), I start not to care too much what's good for them (unless it makes my life eaiser - which is generally how things work). I definitely need a change of attitude. I'm assuming it'll come somehow - perhaps not with this class. She said this is the best class she's ever had. This is the worst class I've ever been in. I don't get it.

I am so swamped (and on LJ?). It's time for bed already but I have so much work to do. Part of the reason that today didn't go so well is because I didn't have lesson plans for the afternoon - so the lessons kind of flopped. I don't have time to always be making lesson plans though.

My plans (that I was unsure of) to go to France for April may have flopped. I can no longer get that cheap ticket price.

BLARGH!

01. I got to sit at the teacher's desk today, and it was just rad doing my work there. It's nice not to work at the back of the class on a makeshift desk.
<lj-cut>02. I've been keeping myself disengaged from the class as much as possible as it's hard to be consistent with classroom management when she is doing most of the teaching.
03. When I taught my math lesson today (3rd lesson so far), it went well despite my boring delivery. The point is that they stayed in their desk nearly 100% of the time, they were quiet, and they ALL finished their work (they pretty much NEVER all finish their work with their regular teacher). They finish their work with me because I give them free time as soon as they are done, and because I use this red card system to make it really easy to see who is done or not. --And yes, I feel a certain tinge of disgust as I write this. Institutionalizing the children. But I know that I'm conscious and thoughtful of the situation (yet could always be more so), and that I'm dealing with a particular class at the moment, the worst I've ever been in for behaviour related issues... excuses, excuses).
04. I have wireless Internet in my classroom. Thus,
05. ...I stayed late today and did my work there. That's so nice, not to have to take it home with me.
06. My house is really supportive and my family is amazing.
07. I'm going to be done school and have a career! I'm going to be a teacher!
08. I like having a big project, and being selective about my social life.

Uh... I taught my first lesson today. WOAH. There is so much to be on top of during a lesson with this particular class. Just getting them to do their work or stay in their desks is a constant battle. I constantly feel like a jerk, or an institutional authoritarian whatever BUT HONESTLY, these kids are not benifiting from having no boundaries. They constantly lie to me, and pretend to cry if I take something away from them. When I take a toy away, they go find another one. It's pretty ridiculous. One kid whines that it's not fair, another stomps away after I've talked to him. Ugh. Anyways, tomorrow I have to try to be better about three things: 01. Keeping track of how teams are doing (I split the class up into teams), and giving them points as they are off task, etc. 02. Stamp their work and give them a red tag when they are done (so they can have free time). 03. Use the 3 chances system when they are off task etc. It'll be nerve wracking for me to make one of them work at the back of the class in front of both my school associate and my faculty associate, but what can I do? One more hurdle jumped tomorrow after my FA has observed me. I think I only have 5 observations from her after that. Sweet. 6.8 weeks left.

So last Friday night I went to bed with images of those boys' faces in my mind. Then I dreamt about babysitting one of them. It was horrible. At least last night I dreamt about Justin Timberlake and trying to make out with some girl. 

So I'm extremely lucky, as I seem to always say, that my sister is helping me so much. She's essentially doing some of the work for me. She's writing my journal reflections and working on this other project for me. Beyond that she is starting to write my science unit! She's pregnant and so has the time. Plus she's just super supportive, has been through the program, etc. She apparently didn't have to do near as much during her practicum and it was in English - bonus!

So I have to teach my first lesson tomorrow morning. Should be interesting with this class. I have to learn to not get so upset when they don't listen to me.

I have so much work to do, just to produce crappy lessons. Too bad they make us produce them in a specific format - I end up spending so much time just typing out drivel.

Anyways, I worked the entire day at my sister's house - fun!

Well off to bed with myself - off to another week of pure joy! It's amazing to think that I only have 7 weeks until I'm over the hump and onwards to an actual career. Blows my mind.
